list.load: {"Category": "system", "Describ": "The load average of the machine describes how many processes are in the run-queue (scheduled to run \"immediately\").", "Title": "Load average", "Plugin": "load", "Vlabel": "load", "Base": "1000", "Infos": {"load": {"info": "5 minute load average", "id": "load", "label": "load"}}, "Order": ""}

list.if_eth2: {"Category": "network", "Describ": "This graph shows the traffic of the eth2 network interface. Please note that the traffic is shown in bits per second, not bytes. IMPORTANT: On 32-bit systems the data source for this plugin uses 32-bit counters, which makes the plugin unreliable and unsuitable for most 100-Mb/s (or faster) interfaces, where traffic is expected to exceed 50 Mb/s over a 5 minute period.  This means that this plugin is unsuitable for most 32-bit production environments. To avoid this problem, use the ip_ plugin instead.  There should be no problems on 64-bit systems running 64-bit kernels.", "Title": "eth2 traffic", "Plugin": "if_eth2", "Vlabel": "bits in (-) / out (+) per ${graph_period}", "Base": "1000", "Infos": {"down": {"cdef": "down,8,*", "min": "0", "graph": "no", "label": "received", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "down"}, "up": {"info": "Traffic of the eth2 interface. Unable to determine interface speed. Please install ethtool, wireless-tools, mii-tool or whatever is appropriate for the interface.", "cdef": "up,8,*", "min": "0", "negative": "down", "label": "bps", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "up"}}, "Order": "down up"}

list.memory: {"Category": "system", "Describ": "This graph shows what the machine uses memory for.", "Title": "Memory usage", "Plugin": "memory", "Vlabel": "Bytes", "Base": "1024", "Infos": {"free": {"info": "Wasted memory. Memory that is not used for anything at all.", "draw": "STACK", "id": "free", "label": "unused"}, "swap_cache": {"info": "A piece of memory that keeps track of pages that have been fetched from swap but not yet been modified.", "draw": "STACK", "id": "swap_cache", "label": "swap_cache"}, "active": {"info": "Memory recently used. Not reclaimed unless absolutely necessary.", "draw": "LINE2", "id": "active", "label": "active"}, "inactive": {"info": "Memory not currently used.", "draw": "LINE2", "id": "inactive", "label": "inactive"}, "committed": {"info": "The amount of memory allocated to programs. list.cpu: {"Category": "system", "Describ": "This graph shows how CPU time is spent.", "Title": "CPU usage", "Plugin": "cpu", "Vlabel": "%", "Base": "1000", "Infos": {"softirq": {"info": "CPU time spent handling \"batched\" interrupts", "draw": "STACK", "min": "0", "label": "softirq", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "softirq"}, "iowait": {"info": "CPU time spent waiting for I/O operations to finish when there is nothing else to do.", "draw": "STACK", "min": "0", "label": "iowait", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "iowait"}, "system": {"info": "CPU time spent by the kernel in system activities", "draw": "AREA", "min": "0", "label": "system", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "system"}, "idle": {"info": "Idle CPU time", "draw": "STACK", "min": "0", "label": "idle", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "idle"}, "user": {"info": "CPU time spent by normal programs and daemons", "draw": "STACK", "min": "0", "label": "user", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "user"}, "irq": {"info": "CPU time spent handling interrupts", "draw": "STACK", "min": "0", "label": "irq", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "irq"}, "nice": {"info": "CPU time spent by nice(1)d programs", "draw": "STACK", "min": "0", "label": "nice", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "nice"}, "steal": {"info": "The time that a virtual CPU had runnable tasks, but the virtual CPU itself was not running", "draw": "STACK", "min": "0", "label": "steal", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "steal"}, "guest": {"info": "The time spent running a virtual CPU for guest operating systems under the control of the Linux kernel.", "draw": "STACK", "min": "0", "label": "guest", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "guest"}}, "Order": "system user nice idle iowait irq softirq"}
list.if_br1000: {"Category": "network", "Describ": "This graph shows the traffic of the br1000 network interface. Please note that the traffic is shown in bits per second, not bytes. IMPORTANT: On 32-bit systems the data source for this plugin uses 32-bit counters, which makes the plugin unreliable and unsuitable for most 100-Mb/s (or faster) interfaces, where traffic is expected to exceed 50 Mb/s over a 5 minute period.  This means that this plugin is unsuitable for most 32-bit production environments. To avoid this problem, use the ip_ plugin instead.  There should be no problems on 64-bit systems running 64-bit kernels.", "Title": "br1000 traffic", "Plugin": "if_br1000", "Vlabel": "bits in (-) / out (+) per ${graph_period}", "Base": "1000", "Infos": {"down": {"cdef": "down,8,*", "min": "0", "graph": "no", "label": "received", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "down"}, "up": {"info": "Traffic of the br1000 interface. Unable to determine interface speed. Please install ethtool, wireless-tools, mii-tool or whatever is appropriate for the interface.", "cdef": "up,8,*", "min": "0", "negative": "down", "label": "bps", "type": "DERIVE", "id": "up"}}, "Order": "down up"}
